At present, seawater electrolysis powered by renewable energy stands as a crucial method for the industrial production of hydrogen. Given the abundance of seawater and its inherently high conductivity, seawater electrolysis earns an increasing interest. Nonetheless, challenges remain, such as the competitive chloride oxidation reaction (COR) caused by chloride ions (Cl‒) and the corrosion of active sites, which hinder the industrial seawater electrolysis. In this review, we initially outline four design strategies aimed at avoiding the occurrence of COR: designing selective oxygen evolution reaction (OER) active sites, anti-corrosion strategies, small molecules oxidize reaction (SMOR) and adjusting electrolyte. Specifically, we compile approaches to enhance the OER selectivity and corrosion resistance in seawater electrolysis, including introducing anion buffer layer. Subsequently, we categorize reported OER catalysts based on their composition and summarize the mechanism underlying their high activity and stability. In conclusion, we address the future challenges and prospects of industrializing seawater electrolysis. Graphical Abstract This paper firstly reviews and discusses the background, challenges and strategies of industrial seawater electrolysis, with particular emphasis on four design strategies to improve anode corrosion resistance and OER selectivity. Then, reported electrocatalysts are classified and discussed. Finally, the paper provides an outlook towards realizing industrial seawater electrolysis for hydrogen production. Keywords Chloride oxidation reaction Chloride ions Oxygen evolution reaction selectivity Seawater electrolysis Anti-corrosion strategies 1 Introduction At present, the demand for replacing traditional fossil energy with cleaner alternatives such as natural gas and hydrogen fuel has become the global focus [1,2]. Hydrogen, in particular, stands out due to its abundant sources and high calorific value, making it a prime candidate for addressing energy challenges [3–5]. Excitedly, water electrolysis has emerged as a promising method to produce hydrogen, as it can directly convert unstable renewable energy sources like wind and solar power into chemical energy, but deeply limited by scarce high-purity water [6–8]. Based on 96.5% of the earth's water resources, seawater is more suitable for large-scale hydrogen production, thus electrolytic seawater has been widely concerned in solving the energy crisis [9,10]. However, seawater electrolysis presents novel challenges, and the primary obstacle arises from the competitive reactions of active chloride ions, which include the chlorine evolution reaction (CER, 2Cl‒ → Cl2 + 2e‒, E 0 = 1.36 V vs. SHE) at low pH and chloride oxidation reaction (COR, Cl‒ + 2OH‒ → OCl‒ + H2O + 2e‒, E 0 = 0.89 V vs. SHE) at high pH. That will inevitable reduce the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) selectivity and lead to deactivation of the catalyst [11–13]. Furthermore, in neutral and alkaline electrolytes, chloride ions (Cl‒) have a natural tendency to cause metal sites to dissolve, predominantly in the form of M-OH, which significantly shortens the lifespan of the anode [14–16]. The corrosion mechanism is specifically characterized by the following steps: (1) At higher anodic potentials, Cl‒ can be readily adsorbed onto the metal active site. (2) Due to the adsorption and permeability of the Cl‒, the metals that make up the framework can easily coordinate with it to form soluble chlorides. (3) Consequently, soluble chloride forms metal hydroxide in an alkaline environment. Thus, the development of efficient and high-selective electrocatalysts for seawater splitting is an urgent necessity to overcome these challenges [17,18]. The precious metal-based materials currently represent the most advanced OER catalysts, is still the most advanced OER catalyst at present, yet their large-scale implementation is hindered by the high cost and limited availability [19–21]. In contrast, transition metal-based materials are not only more abundant but also offer the potential for efficient and stable operation in challenging environments, including harsh conditions and seawater, through surface modifications, such as element doping, heterogeneous structure construction, and defect engineering [22]. For example, Zhang et al. [23] enhanced the overall seawater splitting process by manipulating the d-orbital electronic configuration of transition metal Fe (III) through establishing the heterostructure between iron hydroxide and nickel phosphide. In addition, trace amounts of nitrogen donated additional electrons to CoFeP, thereby accelerating the conductivity of the catalyst materials and enhancing the OER kinetics [24]. Additionally, the introduction of appropriate oxygen defects promoted the downward shift of the Fe-3d band center in NiFeOOH, which further accelerate surface phase transition process [25]. Furthermore, incorporating anti-corrosion strategies, such as the development of anion exclusion layers, electronic structure redistribution, and asymmetric electrolytic cell design, transition metal-based catalysts can exhibit stability and lifespans several times greater than those of precious metals. Currently, these anti-corrosion strategies have been extensively applied to transition metals, alloys, oxides, nitrides, phosphides, carbides, and other materials, significantly propelling the advancement of efficient electrocatalysts for seawater electrolysis. In this review, it is considered that the competition between OER and COR in seawater splitting leads to low Faradaic efficiency (FE) of anode catalyst and serious corrosion of active sites. Moreover, the influence of COR on the reaction system and the necessity of avoiding COR are fully discussed. We compile three comprehensive strategies to address these challenges, including selective OER catalyst, anti-corrosion design, and small molecule oxidation reaction (SMOR) replacing OER. Subsequently, the adjustment of electrolyte could further reduce the occurrence of side reaction and enhance catalytic activity. More importantly, in order to effectively reduce the corrosion of hypochlorite ion (ClO‒) on the active sites in seawater, we specifically summarize anti-corrosion design, such as modifying the electronic structure distribution through surface modification, introducing lattice chlorine, and designing asymmetric electrolytic cell. Subsequently, we categorize and summarize the reported non-noble metal catalysts combining with the study of DFT calculation and catalytic mechanism, which exhibit highly selective and stable seawater electrocatalysis based on hydroxide, oxide, sulfide, phosphide and selenide materials. Finally, we outlook the industrial application prospects of seawater splitting. These findings offer novel insights for the rational design of transition metal electrocatalysts and electrolyzers, aiming to stabilize OER in seawater with high efficiency. 2 Challenges of OER catalysts for seawater electrolysis As mentioned above, the OER typically requires a higher overpotential, which comes down to the complexity of OER. No matter in alkaline or acidic environment, the OER proceeds through four steps. This represents the transfer of proton and electron occurs in multiple stages, inherently leading to low energy conversion efficiency in water splitting. An additional significant challenge is posed by impurity ions present in seawater. On the one hand, a mass of Cl‒ can lead to the occurrence of both the OER and COR (CER) in anode. On account of COR and CER are both oxidation of two electrons, which have a kinetic advantage over OER. Specifically, the CER forming Cl2 dominates the main oxidation reaction when the pH is below 3.0, while the formation of hypochlorous acid (HClO) becomes predominant at pH values ranging from 3.0 to 7.5. Above pH 7.5, the formation of ClO‒ dominates the main reaction [26]. On the other hand, the direct corrosion of anode materials by Cl‒ during seawater electrolysis has been the subject of extensive research and remains a challenging issue. The corrosion mechanisms of anode materials can be primarily categorized into two types: (1) adsorption-induced mechanism and (2) ion migration and permeation models, with the former being more prevalent. Kang et al. [27] discovered that many electrocatalysts and substrates are corroded and dissolved by Cl‒ through the adsorption of chloride ions to form metal chloride or hydroxide. According to the adsorption-induced mechanism (Fig. 1 ), the metal anodic corrosion mechanism consist of passivation process and replacement process with specific reaction equations [28]: Passivation process: xOH‒ + MCl x → MOH x + xCl‒ Replacement process: MO x + 2yCl‒ + yH2O → MO x‒y Cl2y + 2yOH‒ (0 < y < 1) MO x‒y Cl2y + (x‒2y)Cl‒ + (x‒y)H2O → MCl x + (2x‒2y)OH‒ 3 Design criteria of OER catalysts for seawater electrolysis In this section, the research advancements of electrocatalysts in facilitating seawater oxidation is reviewed. We highlight and analyze four key strategies aimed at improving OER selectivity and bolstering the stability of these catalysts, as illustrated in Fig. 2 . These include: (a) creating selective OER sites; (b) anti-corrosion strategies and (c) small molecule oxidation. Furthermore, we provide a balanced critique, discussing the merits and limitations of each of these strategies. 3.1 Electrocatalysts with selective OER sites At present, many studies focus on alkaline design principle, which use higher pH value to provide faster OER kinetics, but the pH of natural seawater is only about 8.4. Obviously, if the electrolyte is not adjusted, it will be difficult to enlarge the overpotential window of OER and COR/CER directly by increasing the pH value. Therefore, developing catalysts with OER selectively active sites is an effective strategy to weaken COR/CER. And this strategy is not pH-dependent and applicable across the full pH range. Exner [36] discussed the linear scaling relationship of single crystal model system RuO2 (110) by deriving a description of CER selectivity consistent with ΔG (OOH) ‒ ΔG (OCl). The conclusion is that the maximum difference of ΔG (OCl) ‒ ΔG (OOH) is a significant measure of high selectivity, which also prove that CER always exhibits lower overpotential than OER. From the volcanic curve (Fig. 3(a) ), it can conclude that the dynamics of CER are milder than those of OER, and the peak values are almost identical, suggesting that it is challenging to create OER selective sites through breaking the scalar relationship [37]. Thus, it is imperative to increase the OER selective catalytic sites. At this stage, most of the OER selective catalysts focus on Co-based and Ru-based catalysts, which have demonstrated exceptional selectivity for OER in neutral saline or phosphate buffer. Keane et al. [38] found Co-Pi could inhibit the oxidation of Cl‒ and Br‒, leading to highly OER selectivity in seawater. This effect can be attributed to the fact that the oxidation kinetics of catalysts are influenced by the reactivity of the substrate edge, thereby preventing the formation of ClO‒ at the edge sites of the clusters (Fig. 3(b)). As the result of differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS) in Fig. 3(c), Co-based or Ni-based catalysts can selectively generate oxygen and trace ClO‒ from seawater. Additionally, the incorporation of Ru not only generates additional OER active sites but also reduces the energy barrier for the rate-limiting step of the OER process (Figs. 3(d) and 3(e)), thereby enhancing the OER selectivity of Co-based catalysts [39]. These works provide guidance for the selection and design of OER catalyst substrates with high selectivity. In addition, several strategies have been identified to create more selective OER sites. For example, adjusting the surface structure and electronic structure of the catalyst can significantly lead to the development of OER selective sites. Kishor et al. [41] reported that the concentration of Cu doping in RuO2 and the dopant position could both have the potential to alter the selectivity between COR and OER. When seawater electrolysis is carried out at a low doping concentration (2%), density functional theory (DFT) indicates that the binding energy of oxygenated intermediates (e.g., HO‒, O‒, HOO‒) is significantly reduced at the active sites of adjacent Ru, thereby enhancing the OER selectivity. However, an increasing in dopant concentration is consistently accompanied by a decrease in OER selectivity, which can be attributed to the dopant occupying the active sites of RuO2 (Table 1 ). Moreover, the increase in Cu dopant content reduces the formation energy of surface oxygen vacancies and facilitates the extra oxygen vacancies for water dissociation, thus enhancing the selectivity of OER. Notably, when Cu is doped at the -br position, it can serve as an active site to reduce the overpotential of OER (η OER = 0.32 eV). This study provides novel insights for developing highly selective OER active sites for neutral seawater splitting. Remarkably, Qiao et al. [40] discovered that the strength of oxygen-containing intermediates in alkaline seawater significantly surpassed that in alkaline pure water at all applied potentials (Fig. 3(f)), demonstrating that Cl‒ was beneficial for the OER activity and stability of electrocatalysts. Unlike the conventional protection mechanism, the high-valent iron (Fe4+) formed at high potential, being a relatively “hard acid,” avoids attack by the “hard base” (OH‒) after adsorbing Cl‒ in seawater, thereby inhibiting the destruction of Fe sites (Fig. 3(g)). This research provides important significant guidance for creating selective active sites. 3.2 OER electrocatalysts with anti-corrosion property In this section, we comprehensively review the latest progress in the design of anti-corrosion electrodes and electrolyzers for seawater splitting. First of all, the anode faces significant interference from the high concentration of dissolved Cl‒ from seawater, which interact with the metal skeleton through an adsorption-reaction-dissolution process. To date, the approaches to design corrosion-resistant electrodes in seawater can be categorized into three main strategies: (1) inherent corrosion-resistant electrodes, (2) corrosion-resistant electrolyzers and (3) recently reported unique corrosion-resistant electrodes, as depicted in Fig. 4 . In addition, we outline the innovative technologies in both direct and indirect seawater splitting equipment and provide a critical assessment of the efficient commercialization potential of seawater electrolysis. 3.2.1 Electrode with inherent-corrosion resistance Transition-metal-based catalysts have swiftly demonstrated comparable excellence to the benchmark RuO2, yet they face a significant challenge in terms of dissolution and deactivation. This is attributed to the formation mechanism of metal chlorides and hydroxides, which is driven by the corrosion of Cl‒ [43]. Specifically, the active metal sites are highly susceptible to etching by Cl‒, which form metal complexes that subsequently dissolve and contribute to the formation of metal hydroxides in the solution, facilitated by the adsorption and permeability of Cl‒ [44]. In response to this issue, there has been a growing emphasis on the design of efficient transition-metal catalysts that simultaneously exhibit reduced chloride adsorption. To address the corrosive effects of Cl‒, three primary strategies have been identified and are discussed in detail below. Firstly, element doping can significantly modulate the adsorption of Cl‒ and oxygen-containing intermediates at active sites. This is a result of the introduction of additional elements, which leads to local charge rearrangement. And the asymmetric charge distribution is crucial for enhancing the adsorption energy of Cl‒ from seawater. As supported by DFT calculation results in Fig. 5(a) , such charge rearrangement can attenuate Cl– adsorption, thereby promoting the OER activity in saturated seawater [45]. Song et al. [46] introduced chromium (Cr) into the CoP lattice, and intensified the eg-t2g orbital splitting of CoP lattice through the unique electron configuration of the Cr-3d orbitals, which facilitate electron transfer in the CoP lattice. The modified CoP exhibited a substantial charge rearrangement, which ensure the stable valence state of the active Co site in seawater and enhance OER selectivity (Figs. 5(b) and (c)). Moreover, Huang's group [47] synthesized an asymmetric Co-N3P1 site by doping P, which lead to the formation of strong oxygen-containing intermediates and disrupt the original electronic structure, preferring to weak Cl‒ adsorption (Fig. 5(d)). In addition, researcher has demonstrated that element doping can markedly accelerate the self-reconstruction process. For example, as depicted in the Raman spectrum in Fig. 5(e), the incorporation of cobalt significantly reduced the overpotential of Ni2P to NiOOH, enhanced the formation of highly selective adsorption sites for hydroxide ions (OH‒) on the electrode surface, while simultaneously inhibited the adsorption of Cl‒ (Fig. 5(f)) [48]. Furthermore, the self-reconstruction process can be accelerated through the creation of heterostructure. Bao et al. [49] developed a unique electron channel (Ni-O-Fe) between Ni-BDC and NM88B (Fe), as shown in Fig. 5(g), which accelerated the reconstruction process during seawater oxidation. Moreover, NiFeOOH formed on the electrode surface was considered as a protective layer, which reduced the toxic effect of Cl‒ on the anode [50]. Notably, Cl vacancy can direct the adsorption of Cl‒ through defect engineering, thereby preventing the inactivation of active sites [51]. Zhuang et al. [12] utilized the vacancies created by the continuous leaching of lattice Cl‒ as a structural buffer to resist corrosion in seawater. During the OER process, the O-Co-Cl site of Co2(OH)3Cl could balance the lattice Cl‒ leaching and electrolyte Cl‒ incorporation, and avoid the deactivation of the real active site (Co) (Figs. 5(h) and (i)). These studies provide a scientific understanding of the mechanism underlying the competitive adsorption between Cl‒ ion and the reaction intermediates from the electronic structure perspective. 3.2.2 Special mechanism Based on the universal protection mechanism, the anode can significantly mitigate corrosion caused by Cl‒. Nevertheless, the pursuit of high corrosion resistance in seawater electrodes requires novel approaches. Some studies have highlighted a unique protective mechanism that offers fresh insights for designing electrodes capable of withstanding the challenging conditions of seawater electrocatalysis. For example, Shen et al. [52] introduced an innovative in-situ double-layer strategy specifically aiming at addressing chloride-induced corrosion. In the Ni-Fe-Ce-B/MS, Ce element and B element were oxidized to form CeO2 protective layer (inside) and B(OH)4 ‒ anions buffer layer (outside), respectively (Figs. 6(a) and 6(b) ). The NiFeOOH, featuring a double-layer coating, successfully resisted the adsorption of Cl‒, exhibiting robust catalytic stability in 1.0 mol L‒1 KOH + seawater (1.0 mol L‒1 KOH + sw) for over 100 h [52]. However, although the coating of CeO2, MnNiO4 and carbon layer can reduce the toxicity of Cl‒ to anode, it will undoubtedly block the active sites and hinder the release of oxygen bubbles, thus affecting the catalytic activity. Considering the limited permeability of the traditional protective layer, Lin et al. [53] developed an operando reconstructed molecule protective fence with enhanced permeability. This fence utilized stable aromatic ring-containing tetra-cyanoquinodimethane (TCNQ) molecules to effectively anchor SO4 2‒. As shown in Fig. 6(c), the unique structure depicted effectively immobilized acidic ions on the electrode surface while simultaneously preventing the penetration of Cl‒. In addition, the effective design of Lewis acid layer could also indirectly avoid chloride corrosion and precipitation formation on the electrodes. This was due to the formation of a stable electrical double layer (EDL) by unreacted OH‒ together with the positive charge around the anode surface (Fig. 6(d)). The excess OH‒ within the EDL preferentially accumulated, electrostatically repelling Cl‒ and reducing their invasion. As shown in Figs. 6(e) and (f), the Lewis acid layer (Cr2O3) generated a concentration of excess OH‒ on the surface of Cr2O3-CoO x , which was sufficient to resist Cl‒, thereby resulting in a chemical surface composition of CoO x with minimal Cl‒ presence [54]. Moreover, the intrinsic activity of the electrocatalysts was significantly enhanced in the local acidic environment, approaching the activity levels observed for CoO x in natural seawater. This offers a general strategy for realizing direct seawater electrolysis (Fig. 6(g)) [55,56]. These studies provide valuable insights and directions for reassessing the anti-corrosion strategy of anode in seawater. 3.2.3 Design of corrosion-resistant electrolyzers The reasonable design of electrolyzers is crucial for enhancing the lifespan of the electrodes. Based on the four mainstream electrolyzers including alkaline water electrolyzers (AWE) [57], proton exchange membrane water electrolysis (PEMWE), proton exchange membrane water electrolyzers (AEMWE) [58], and solid oxide electrolysis cell (SOEC) [59]) (Fig. 7 ), it becomes apparent that the primary causes of performance degradation (voltage drop) are related to: (1) the attack of anions on the functional groups within the membrane, leading to the degradation of the polymer and subsequently increasing the membrane's fragility, and (2) the dissolution of the anode or the precipitation of metals, which can block active sites and reduce catalytic activity [42,60]. To date, the corrosion impact of electrolyzers can be effectively reduced through the implementation of in-situ water purification and asymmetric design [58,61]. Asymmetric electrolyzers are designed to circulate diverse electrolyte solutions within bipolar chambers, while selectively allowing only specific ions to pass through treated exchange membranes [62]. Firstly, asymmetric feeding mode can form asymmetric electrolyzers by leveraging the selective permeability of the exchange membrane. The asymmetric feeding approach, specifically the anode feeding mode, prevents anions (such as Cl‒, Br‒) from migrating towards the anode through the membrane. In addition, the elevated pH environment around the anode promotes the kinetics of OER (Fig. 8(a) ) [58]. During durability test (Fig. 8(b)), the electrolyzers obviously exhibited excellent corrosion resistance, thoroughly validating the feasibility of anode feeding mode. In addition, an asymmetric electrolytic cell with a bipolar chamber serving as a flow channel can effectively mitigate anode corrosion. In this configuration, a NaCl solution or natural seawater is circulated in the cathode cavity, while a NaOH solution is circulated in the anode cavity. Distinct from unilateral feeding, the two bipolar chambers within the asymmetric electrolytic cell, separated by Na+ exchange membranes, can simultaneously support the flow of electrolyte (Figs. 8(c) and (d)). This feeding mode not only prevents Cl– from reaching the anode via the exchange membrane but also averts the precipitation of metal ions at the cathode (pH < 9.5), significantly improving the stability of seawater electrolysis [59]. Owing to the substantial pH gradient between real seawater and NaOH, this chemical potential difference can diminish the voltage requirement for direct seawater electrolysis, offering insights for direct seawater electrolysis. For direct seawater electrolysis, Xie et al. [63] provided a direct seawater electrolysis method reduce the impact of side effects and corrosion. As shown in Fig. 8(e), the mechanism of strategy is to achieve the migration of water from seawater to a self-dampening electrolyte (SDE) through liquid-gas-liquid phase changing by the water vapor pressure difference between seawater and SDE. 3.3 Small molecules oxidize to replace OER Given the relatively sluggish kinetic of OER and its high theoretical potential along with a competitive overpotential, numerous studies have resorted to a strategy that replaces the anode reaction with SMOR, such as the urea oxidation reaction (UOR), ethylene glycol oxidation reaction (EGOR) and glycerol oxidation reaction (GOR) (Fig. 9 ). These SMOR reactions are thermodynamically more advantageous than OER. Moreover, the SMOR instead of OER has the following advantages: (1) The products of SMOR typically have higher economic value. (2) The SMOR completely avoids COR in seawater. (3) The SMOR can be carried out at a lower initial voltage than OER, which translates to reduced energy consumption for the production of an equivalent amount of hydrogen (Fig. 10(a) ) [64]. SMOR frequently demonstrates high selectivity at low current density. Xiang et al. [65] synthesized a Co (OH)2@HOS/CP bifunctional electrocatalyst to facilitate the production of hydrogen while converting methanol to valuable formate via the formic acid oxidation reaction, achieving 100% (FE) for both anodic and cathodic processes. Consequently, SMOR is capable of functioning in challenging environments, such as seawater or sewage (Fig. 10(b)) [66,67]. For example, Leandro et al. [68] encapsulated Pt within few-layered graphene (Fig. 10(c)) and effectively promoted GOR in seawater through strong metal-support interaction (SMSI). The analysis revealed that the primary products of glycerol oxidation include glyceric acid, tartaric acid and other C2 or C1 products, with no detectable derivatives of Cl2 and ClO‒. Furthermore, the composition ratio of the key components in the products could be adjusted by modifying the temperature conditions, thereby allowing GOR to further mitigate the occurrence of OER (Fig. 10(d)). Notably, Liu's team replaced OER with a significantly low anodic potential of methanol oxidation reaction (MOR), completely bypassing COR in seawater. In alkaline natural seawater (1 mol L‒1 KOH + 1 mol L‒1 CH3OH + seawater), the presence of Cl‒ ion hardly affected the cell's activity, and it can operate for 120 h at 10 mA cm‒2 without obvious degradation (Figs. 10(e) and (f)) [69]. Although the advantages of SMOR-assisted seawater electrolysis are evident, several technical challenges remain to be addressed. Firstly, a viable method is still required for the separation and purification of anode products. Secondly, there is a lack of specific electrocatalyst design for SMOR. Furthermore, ensuring high selectivity and stability at high current density poses a significant challenge, indicating that substantial progress is needed to realize industrial application. 4 Method for adjusting electrolyte As a four-electron reaction, the kinetics of OER is relatively slow [70,71]. Despite the fact that certain electrocatalysts demonstrate commendable catalytic efficiency, side reaction cannot be completely avoided. Lately, there has been a notable investigation into the impact of modifying the surface in seawater electrolytes, which has shown promise in not only enhancing the reaction kinetics but also in mitigating the occurrence of side reaction. In Fig. 11 , the process of adjusting seawater electrolytes can be broadly categorized into two approaches: (1) alkaline design criterion and (2) ion buffer layer around the anode. 4.1 OER electrocatalysts based on alkaline design criterion Generally, seawater acts as a kind of unbuffered electrolyte and is susceptible to developing acidic conditions around the anode, which exacerbates the formation of hypochlorite during seawater electrolysis. Although the carbon dioxide system in seawater as the primary buffering agent, it has a limited impact on eliminating the local pH fluctuations around the cathode and anode. Consequently, the electrolysis process necessitates other buffers to prevent localized pH fluctuation [72]. According to pourbaix diagram in Fig. 12(a) , chlorine formed under acidic conditions and hypochlorite produced under alkaline conditions unavoidably influences the selectivity of OER. However, when the process is carried out under alkaline conditions (pH > 7.5), there exists a maximum potential window reaching 480 mV separating OER and COR, indicating the potential to develop OER catalysts with overpotentials below 480 mV (Fig. 12(b)) [73]. Based on this thermodynamic analysis and the kinetic disparities between COR and OER, an alkaline design criterion has been proposed to facilitate the development of highly selective OER catalysts [74,75]. At present, the frontier research of seawater electrolysis is aim to develop efficient electrocatalysts with the ability to operate at high current densities with minimal overpotential. Experimental evidence confirmed that Ni-Fe layered double hydroxide (LDH) catalysts are inherently restricted in the process of neutral seawater electrolysis, which exhibits low activity and significant instability. However, at pH 13, Ni-Fe LDH nanosheets loaded on various carriers were found to operate safely in seawater with high selectivity, and exhibited exceptional activity and stability. This study demonstrates the feasibility of alkaline design strategy for the development of highly selective seawater splitting catalysts (Figs. 12(c)) [76]. Subsequently, Nakayama et al. discovered the change of electrochemical window between OER and COR with local pH through Fig. 12(d). The results show that from pH 7 to 11, the electrochemical window between OER and COR was maintained about 370 mV, and higher pH value (pH > 12) made OER has more obvious thermodynamic advantages. From Figs. 12(e) and (f), it was evident that the COR selectivity of various anode catalysts is 0 when the pH value exceeds 12. This finding further substantiates the thermodynamic superiority of the OER in alkaline seawater [77]. Based on the thermodynamic superiority of the OER in alkaline salt water, numerous studies have since applied LDH to alkaline seawater splitting. Wu et al. [78] prepared Ni3S2-embedded NiFe LDH heterostructure nanosheets through one-pot method. Notably, the electrolytic cell composed of Ni3S2-NiFe LDHs/NF-2 and Ru-Ni3S2-NiFe can achieve a commercial current density of 500 mA cm‒2 at 1.85 V. Kim et al. [29] fabricated thin layers of Na2Co1‒x Fe x P2O7 nanoparticles (NCFPO/C NPs) uniformly coated on a carbon carrier. During the OER process, in situ hydroxide layer formed on the NCFPO/C NPs was the main reaction site. At a fixed current density of 100 mA cm‒2, it exhibited a low overpotential of less than 480 mV in alkaline seawater (Fig. 12(g)). Additionally, compared with neutral salt water, NCFPO/C as anode did not produce reactive chloride species after chronopotentiometric test in simulated alkaline seawater, indicating that NCFPO/C may exhibit excellent OER selectivity in alkaline seawater (Fig. 12(h)). In summary, both theoretical analysis and experimental evidence prove that the alkaline design criterion can effectively inhibit the occurrence of COR while enhancing the performance of OER, thereby ensuring the high stability and selectivity of seawater splitting process. 4.2 Electrode with ion buffer layer At the anode, adding oxygen-containing anions to seawater electrolyte serves as an effective chloride repulsion strategy. Theoretical calculations and in-situ experiments have shown that major thermodynamically stable anions (e.g., SO4 2‒, PO4 3‒, etc.) are preferentially adsorbed onto the anode surface or within the intercalation layer. And this results in the electrostatic repulsion of Cl‒ in the bulk phase, thereby effectively preventing their diffusion to the catalyst surface [51,79]. Ma et al. [80] confirmed that the presence of SO4 2‒ in the electrolyte significantly mitigate chloride corrosion of the anode in real seawater, ensuring the stable performance of nickel-based catalysts for 500‒1000 h (Fig. 13(a) ). Considering that most (pre-) catalysts with non-active-site elements (e.g., S, P, Mo, C, Se…) are naturally converted into oxygen-containing anions during the oxidation process (Fig. 13(b)) [81–83], these formed oxyanions are further dissolved and preferentially adsorbed on the intercalation or shell of the material. This phenomenon offers a novel design dimension to improve a ultra-stable layer and extensive active area of transition metal-based catalysts [84]. For example, RuMoNi alloy was reconstructed in electrochemical process, with MoO4 2– forming in situ on the surface of RuO2, effectively repelling Cl‒ and exhibiting no corrosive effects on the electrode. RuO2 and MoO4 2– were formed by leaching Ru and Mo from RuMoNi electrocatalyst during electrochemical process (Fig. 13(c)). On the surface of nickel foam carrier, the reversible dissolution and precipitation between MoO4 2– and NiMoO4 ensure the stable existence of MoO4 2– at the electrochemical interface [85]. Furthermore, the electrolytic process of depositing Ni-Fe hydroxide on Ni-Fe/NiS x -Ni created sulfate (NiS x ) and carbonate, which act as anode protection layer with exceptional chloride rejection properties. This configuration exhibited superior catalytic activity and corrosion resistance in industrial current alkaline seawater electrolysis [86]. Nevertheless, the elevated concentration of oxygen-containing anions within the highly active LDH intercalation frequently leads to an ion concentration exchange, specifically the exchanging of acid radical ions with Cl‒, which will lead to the collapse or peeling of the layered structure. On the one hand, designing LDH as a monolayered porous nanostructure can effectively avoid Cl‒ corrosion [87]. On the other hand, the influence of Cl‒ can be mitigated by diminishing the ion concentration exchange process, in accordance with the ion-exchange equilibrium constants for LDHs, which rank as follows: CO3 2– > SO4 2– > OH‒ > Cl > Br‒. Fortunately, the interlayer spacing of the nanosheets can be precisely controlled by adjusting the metal composition in the host layer and the structure within the interlayer galleries. An appropriately adjusted interlayer spacing can facilitate the passage of small-sized ions such as CO3 2– and SO4 2– and concurrently limiting the invasion of Cl‒ (Fig. 13(d)). Under these conditions, the exchange of Cl‒ with interlayer acid ions is scarcely detectable, effectively preventing the structural collapse or delamination of the LDH layered structure during seawater electrolysis (Fig. 13(e)) [65,84,88]. Recently, a SCI strategy has been introduced to combat the common ionic effect of Cl‒, wherein free Cl‒ was immobilized in a more stable state (AgCl) on the anode surface under the influence of an applied electric field [89]. Moreover, the Cl‒ fixed on the surface did not impact the interior of catalysts and could significantly reduce the adsorption of Cl‒ (Figs. 13(f) and (g)). As depicted in Figs. 13(h) and (i), the highly dispersed Cl‒ layer ensured that the NiFe LDH@Ag catalyst could operate at a current density of 400 mA cm–2 in alkaline salt electrolyte for over 5000 h, indicating that NiFe LDH@Ag possesses corrosion resistance and stability that far surpass those of NiFe LDH. Consequently, the judicious design and development of anion layer substantially extend the lifespan of anodes, warranting further research and development efforts. 5 OER electrocatalysts At present, the anodic corrosion caused by Cl‒ in seawater medium remains a significant obstacle to seawater splitting. Researchers have recently been concentrating on the development of corrosion-resistant non-noble metal-based catalysts. To enhance the conductivity and stability of these specialized compounds, the primary anti-corrosion approach continues to be the manipulation of their electronic structures through elemental doping, heterostructure construction, defect engineering, and so on [90–93]. In this section, we present an overview of the most advanced transition metal-based OER electrocatalysts for seawater splitting. These catalysts are classified based on the types of metal compounds, such as hydroxide, oxide, sulfide, selenide and phosphide. We then discuss their synthesis strategies, structural characterization and selective OER performance individually. 5.1 Metal-hydroxide electrocatalysts Metal LDHs and their derivatives emerge as dependable alternatives to noble metal catalysts, owing to their superior catalytic ability for the OER [94]. Furthermore, LDHs have demonstrated remarkable corrosion resistance in seawater by accommodating anions and altering the interlayer spacing [95–97]. For example, a porous sulfur-doped Ni-Fe LDH was synthesized via a rapid room-temperature synthesis strategy with exceptional OER performance in alkaline natural seawater, which can be attributed to the high concentration of selective active sites [98]. Lu et al. [89] prepared Ag-doped NiFe LDH, also achieving efficient and stable electrolyte for 5000 h at 400 mA cm–2. The stability was stemmed from the oxidation of Ag, which stabilized the lattice oxygen, avoided the collapse of anode materials, and ensured progression of lattice oxygen mechanism (LOM). To enhance overall seawater splitting, Wang et al. [103] synthesized NiFe LDH on sulfur-modified nickel molybdate nanorods (S-NiMoO4). Here, the S-NiMoO4 nanorods were responsible for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) activity, while the NiFe LDH played a major role in OER performance. Additionally, sulfur was leached from the anode, resulting in the formation of a stable anion-rich layer in-situ, thereby yielding a bifunctional electrocatalyst with excellent resistance to Cl‒ corrosion. It has also been proved that Co-Fe LDH is an efficient electrocatalyst for water oxidation, yet the underlying mechanism for its superior OER activity in seawater remains unexplained [100]. A report explained that the complex polyions can accelerate the reaction kinetics of Co-Fe LDH in seawater, which can be attributed to the proton transfer and electron transfer reactions mediated by NaCl, MgCl2 or Na2SO4 [101]. This offers a novel understanding of the influence of Cl‒ ions on the electrode. Some other polymetallic hydroxide electrocatalysts [87,102] (mainly composed of Ni, Fe, Al, Co, Ir and other metal elements) and their performance for alkaline seawater electrolysis are shown in Table 2 . 5.2 Metal-oxide electrocatalysts In the initial research on seawater splitting with metal oxides, it was observed that noble metal oxides demonstrated excellent catalytic activity and stability in both acidic and alkaline environments. For example, the stability of RuO2 and IrO2 in both acidic and alkaline environments was 2‒3 times higher than that of the corresponding metals, as depicted in Fig. 14(a) [116]. Nevertheless, the high cost associated with these catalysts has necessitated the exploration of alternative and effective transition metal oxide electrocatalysts. In this view, we present a comprehensive classification and summary of the characteristics and OER performance within transition metal oxides. Manganese (Mn) is abundant element on the earth, which can form manganese oxide within specific potential and pH ranges (Fig. 14(b)) [117]. Due to its stable structure, manganese oxide (MnO x ) generally serves a protective role by reducing the corrosion of Cl‒ on active sites in seawater, rather than functioning as an active site for OER. And MnO x has been extensively utilized in seawater electrolysis to efficiently stabilize the OER process. By combining in-situ Raman spectra of OER reconstruction process and DFT on the MnO x surface, it can be unambiguously concluded that a scalar relationship between the adsorption energies of HOO* and HO* intermediates must be overcome to enhance the activity of MnO x (Fig. 14(c)) [117–121]. And it is noteworthy that the surface and internal structure of MnO x materials significantly impact the electrocatalyst activity [122]. Bigiani et al. [123] constructed the heterojunction between the original oxides (Mn (IV)/Mn (III) oxides) and FTO (Fe2O3 or Co3O4), accelerating the separation of charge carriers, and thus enhancing OER activity (Fig. 14(d)). In alkaline seawater electrolysis, these materials exhibited ultra-low Tafel slope (Figs. 14(e) and (f)). In addition, the overpotential of the target electrode kept below 480 mV, thereby preventing chloride corrosion during alkaline seawater electrolysis. Moreover, Kang et al. [124] manipulated the interlayer spacing of the bilayer manganese oxide electrocatalysts to control the overpotential within the range of 0.45 to 0.68 V, demonstrating that the unique structural properties of MnO x confer significant catalytic activity towards OER. As depicted in Fig. 14(g), γ-MnO2 demonstrated stability over 8000 h without any significant performance degradation [125]. Nickel-based oxides are commonly employed in the OER due to their impressive catalytic performance under alkaline conditions. However, improving the oxidation state of Ni is a crucial factor for enhancing OER activity, which effectively reduce the overpotential of seawater splitting and avoid side reaction [126]. Moreover, NiO x stands out as an electrode material with exceptional corrosion resistance in seawater. Yu et al. [127] generated an NiOOH shell in-situ by applying potential around NiMoN nanorods, which is beneficial for the high stability and OER selectivity [128–130]. During seawater splitting, cobalt-based oxides with spinel structure (e.g., CoO, Co2O3 and Co3O4.), are regarded as robust OER electrocatalysts in seawater. In particular, spinel Co3O4 is not only inexpensive but also exhibits high OER activity in both acidic and alkaline media, however, albeit with some stability concerns [128,131]. Remarkably, bifunctional groups containing Co are beneficial to inhibit anodic oxidation reconstruction and selective OER. Wang et al. [132] reported that MoO3@CoO/CC achieved long-term stability over 1000 h at 600 mA cm‒2 and high selectivity with the FE of ~100% (Fig. 15(a) ). The CoMo-LDH phase barrier layer formed on its surface can not only hinder the adsorption of Cl‒, but also limit the deep interface reconstruction, thus stable operating in natural seawater reducing the corrosion of the electrocatalyst (Figs. 15(a) and (b)). In addition, Thanh et al. conducted an in-depth investigation into the relationship between the OER activity and stability of Co3O4. XPS analysis revealed that the ratio of Co2+/Co3+ on the electrode surface is influenced by the deposition thickness of Co3O4 (Fig. 15(c)). Consequently, optimizing the moderate thickness of Co3O4 can provide a balance between OER activity and stability [126,133,134]. Furthermore, alternative approaches can enhance the OER activity and stability of Co3O4. Ling et al. [54] d-eposited a Lewis acid layer on CoO x , which effectively facilitates to the utilization of transition metal oxides in natural seawater splitting (Fig. 15(d)). In non-alkalized or acidified seawater electrolyte, the hard Lewis acid layer on the catalyst surface can significantly promote the water splitting and capture the hydroxyl anion (OH‒) generated in-situ, thus achieving the increasing of local pH (Fig. 15(e)). Remarkably, the enrichment of local OH‒ effectively hindered the diffusion and adsorption of Cl‒ on the catalyst surface, thus inhibiting the occurrence of ClOR. Moreover, the strong combination between local OH‒ and Lewis acid layer also reduces the precipitation of Mg2+ and Ca2+ on the CoO x surface (Figs. 15(f) and (g)). Iron-based oxides are considered as dependable alternatives for OER electrocatalysts due to their abundant reserves and simple preparation. Moreover, in acidic environment, iron can spontaneously form stable Fe2O3 and Fe3O4, as depicted in the Pourbaix diagrams of iron in Fig. 15(h). Nevertheless, compared with cobalt-based oxides, iron-based oxides are not considered as superior OER electrocatalysts [122]. The reasons are that: (1) the wide band-gap of FeO x exhibits inadequate conductivity; (2) Fe sites are prone to corrosion and dissolution by halogens. Therefore, altering the electronic configuration of the Fe 3d orbitals becomes crucial [135,136]. For example, the strong adsorption of oxygen-containing intermediates (OH*) on the surface of Fe3O4 diminishes the OER activity. Li et al. [92] enhanced the DOS near the Fermi level of Fe3O4 by incorporating Cr (Fig. 15(i)), thereby demonstrating excellent activity along with robust stability in alkaline seawater and domestic sewage. And our group significantly adjusted Fe3O4 by doping Ru and P, and the d-band center of Fe 3d moved up obviously, which decrease the adsorption energy of Cl‒ from seawater, thus achieving stable seawater splitting (Figs. 15(j) and (k)) [137]. In addition, depositing CeO x on the anode surface can selectively permit the passage of OER intermediates without hampering the OER activity, while also prevents redox ions from diffusing through the layer. In stability test, the overpotential of NiFeO x electrode declined by over 60 mV within 96 h (1.53 V vs. RHE), however, NiFeO x coated with CeO x maintained an stable overpotential at 20 mA cm‒2 over 96 h [138]. This approach also offers a novel strategy for improving the selectivity and durability of electrocatalyst in different solvents. Besides, several different monometallic oxides have also demonstrated excellent OER performance [11,138–141]. At present, the introduction of other metal elements through element doping can significantly increase the OER activity. For example, the combination of NiO x with other metals (such as Mn, Co, Fe and Zn) has been observed to effectively form highly oxidized Ni. This is attributed to the doping metal elements significantly reduces the binding energy of Ni-O, thereby affecting the deprotonation of OH* groups on Ni sites and the O-O coupling process in OER mechanism [142]. During OER process in seawater, the oxidation state of metals can also be improved. Qiao et al. [40] found that among bimetallic (Ni and Fe) sites, Fe can selectively adsorb Cl‒ from seawater, avoiding the poisoning of the actual active site Ni. This results in an increase in the Ni valence state and a decrease in the Fe valence state, thereby stabilizing the lattice oxygen. Generally, altering the density of oxygen defects in metal oxides can modify the electronic structure and accelerate the surface reconstruction, which is conducive to stabilize the adsorption of oxygen containing intermediates, thus preventing the direct corrosion of Cl‒ in seawater [143–145]. Debnath et al. [146] manipulated oxygen defects to convert spinel-structured CoFe2O4 into bifunctional electrocatalyst for both HER and OER within a specific pH range. The obvious synergistic effect between Co3+/Fe3+ and Co/Fe enhanced the OER activity. In addition, the disordered MnO x nano-layer introduces oxygen vacancies into MnO x nano-layer, leading to higher selectivity of OER on MnO x surface than that of COR, which can be attributed to the high concentration oxygen vacancies induced by lattice disorder [147]. Furthermore, it has been reported that the OER selectivity of anode materials can be significantly improved by designing bimetallic oxide electrocatalysts with heterostructure. Vos et al. [148] covered the MnO x film onto glassy carbon-loaded IrO x to enhancing OER selective. Subsequent studies revealed that the MnO x film was not catalytically active during electrolysis, but rather the IrO x covered by the MnO x film was no longer conducive to Cl‒ transport. As shown in Figs. 16(a) and (b) , OER on metal oxide surface is usually divided into adsorbed evolution mechanism (AEM) and lattice oxygen mechanism (LOM). LOM usually exhibits a smaller theoretical overpotential than AEM, but its stability is far less than AEM, which is due to the participation of lattice oxygen (Fig. 16(c)). Therefore, regulating AEM to LOM provides a promising alternative way to break through OER activity. A report proved that the change of reaction pathway on the surface of Sr-doped layered perovskite oxide through experiments and DFT calculations. In Fig. 16(d), DOS proved that the O 2p level of RP-Sr75 is closer to Fermi level, which promotes the outflow of electrons from oxygen sites. Under the applied potential, the redox potential of O2/H2O can be consistent with the energy of O 2p state, thus generating holes in ligand oxygen and inducing LOM [149]. In addition, we summarize the excellent catalytic performance of some advanced multi-metal oxide electrocatalysts [139,145,150] (Specific performance is shown in Table 3 ). 5.3 Metal-phosphide electrocatalysts Transition metal phosphides (TMPs) are extremely unstable and prone to phase change during OER process [166–168]. Consequently, the OER activity of metal phosphides is derived from the corresponding oxidation or hydroxide derivatives. Combined with DFT calculation, we can further understand the promotion mechanism of catalytic activity and corrosion resistance [169,170]. In the case of conventional NiFeP, the OER process generated phosphorus-containing NiOOH on the surface of NiFeP, which serve as the main sites to enhance the OER activity. In addition, the ligand effect of P adjusted the electronic distribution of the catalytic site, thereby reducing the adsorption energy difference between HO* and O* from 0.98 to 0.69 eV (Fig. 16(e)) [171]. Recently, the corrosion of anode in seawater has been effectively mitigated through designing multi-component phosphide. Ren et al. [172] synthesized a bimetallic heterogeneous phosphide Ni2P-Fe2P through a three-step process, exhibiting extensive electrochemical active area and rich active sites. The alloying of Ni and Fe enhanced the corrosion resistance in seawater. In addition, Hu's group [173] constructed a ternary heterojunction of crystalline Ni2P, Fe2P, and CeO2 on NF to create an efficient and durable OER electrocatalyst for seawater splitting. The superior OER catalytic activity and corrosion resistance over long periods can be attributed to the adjustable electronic structure and the chemical stability imparted by electronegative P atoms. During the OER process, electrocatalytic activity of the phosphides surpassed that of P-free composites. This may be due to the influx of P and the sulfate formed in-situ, which mitigate the adsorption of Cl‒ on the active site through electrostatic repulsion. However, while this mechanism may shorten the service life of the electrocatalyst, the optimized anode can still maintain durability in the range of 100 to 1000 h. In addition, further surface modification can further accelerate the reconstruction and electron redistribution of metal phosphide on the surface. Wang et al. [174] pre-analyzed the electron distribution in doped and vacancy-engineered Ni2P by DFT. From Bader charge in Figs. 16(f)‒(h), the relative equilibrium state in the original model Ni2P was broken by Fe doping and partial P atom removal. Specifically, the charge density around Ni decreased due to electron redistribution after doping and vacancy engineering, which will directly lead to the enhancement of electron interaction, thus improving the electrochemical performance. Accelerating the step from O* to OOH* is the key to accelerating OER. Ni 3d DOS (Fig. 16(i)) showed that the treated NiP is more inclined to adsorb OOH*, and accelerating the formation of Ni OOH on the surface (Fig. 16(j)), which is consistent with the in-situ Raman results in Figs. 16(k) and (l) [174]. 5.4 Metal chalcogenide electrocatalysts Transition metal chalcogenide (TMC) generally display superior electrical conductivity compared to metal oxides and hydroxides [168]. Among these, transition metal sulfide nanomaterials (TMS) are often synthesized under milder conditions than their counterpart metal carbides, etc. [175]. Similar to metal phosphides, metal sulfides have a propensity to be oxidized into corresponding amorphous oxides or (oxygen) hydroxides in alkaline media. And the sulfur on the surface of the material further forms oxygen-containing anions and generates sulfur vacancies in-situ. For example, Ru-NiCo2S4‒x formed an outer layer of NiCoOOH during the OER process as a truly active species, and the sulfur vacancy formed on the surface can accelerate the reconstruction process [176]. Another example is the uniform growth of a three-dimensional vertical array of Ni3S2/Co3S4 (NiCoS) nanosheets on NF. In the process of alkaline seawater electrolysis, nickel/cobalt (oxygen) hydroxide was formed in-situ on the surface of anode, exposing abundant active sites on the oxidized surface, and the formation of sulfate layer significantly enhanced chloride corrosion resistance [177]. Transition metal selenides (TMSe) (Co-Se and Co9Se8 phases) exhibit similar properties after the OER process. The surface of cobalt and selenium was transformed into OER active cobalt hydroxide within an hour, which markedly improves catalytic activity. With its intrinsic three-dimensional network structure and strong connection between cobalt selenide and cobalt substrate, cobalt selenide electrode demonstrated excellent OER performance and stability [178]. It was also noteworthy that TMSe possesses an almost optimal electronic filled in with eg orbitals, and manifested by the moderate adsorption energy of the oxygen-containing intermediate. When Se and Mo coexist, they can jointly induce lattice defects and disordered structures, facilitating the formation of shells rich in multivalent anions (MoO x n‒ and SeO x n‒), thereby collectively providing a protective layer against chloride corrosion [179,180]. 5.5 Other electrocatalysts Here, we summarize some other types of OER electrocatalysts in seawater, such as cRu-Ni3N [181], C-MFECs [182], Co2B [183] and single-atom catalysts [184] so on. Carbon-based metal-free electrocatalysts (C-MFECs) are a new field of electrocatalytic research, which has obvious advantages of high efficiency and low cost. In addition, C-MFECs were not affected by Co-poisoning effect, and exhibited excellent catalytic activity, selectivity and durability. As for transition metal nitrides (TMNs) and transition metal carbides (TMC), the stability improvement in the process of seawater splitting is also suitable for the strategy of TMPs. And the composition, structure and performance of different catalysts are related to each other, which is the basis for rational design and construction of efficient electrocatalysts. Furthermore, we introduce the latest reported catalysts, including nitride, ionic liquid, chlorophyll, heterojunction electrocatalysts and various nanocomposite electrocatalysts, etc. The OER performance of specific electrocatalysts is shown in Table 4 . 6 Conclusions and outlook Seawater electrolysis, powered by renewable energy, is emerging as an inevitable trend in energy conversion systems. It is considered as a revolutionary technology that could replace fresh water for large-scale hydrogen production. Nevertheless, seawater electrolysis has to overcome several challenges: (1) The competitive reaction (COR) and corrosion of metal sites caused by Cl‒ result in poor OER selectivity and stability in seawater. (2) Stability and service life of seawater electrolysis equipment. Addressing these challenges is imperative to enhance the activity, selectivity, and corrosion resistance during natural seawater electrolysis. This review surveys the achievements of electrocatalysts with heightened selectivity and corrosion resistance, delving into the fundamental principles, mechanisms, and the challenges of seawater corrosion at the anode. Then we focus on the strategic design of electrocatalysts that are resistant to Cl‒ in seawater. Specifically, we first elucidate the corrosion mechanism and the impact driven by Cl– on the activity of anode materials, which aim to systematically elucidate the correlation between Cl‒ and OER performance during seawater electrolysis. Consequently, a novel control strategy for Cl‒ is proposed, which is instrumental in reducing the occurrence of competitive reactions (COR). Although there has been a marked improvement in the selectivity and stability of seawater electrocatalysts, the development of efficient OER catalysts remains a formidable challenge to meet the demands of low-cost and large-scale natural seawater electrolysis. To overcome these obstacles, we propose several future research perspectives in Fig. 17 . Initially, natural seawater served as an unbuffered electrolyte, which can lead to the formation of ClO‒ and corrosion around the anode. While anode materials can readily overcome the overpotential of corrosion and achieve 100% OER selectivity in alkaline seawater, this process inevitably contributes to water pollution and highly costs. Moreover, during neutral seawater electrolysis, the low concentration of hydroxide ions (*OH) hinders the anode materials from exhibiting optimal catalytic activity and stability. Consequently, there is an urgent need for more profound theoretical insights and effective strategies to control the *OH concentration on the anode surface in neutral seawater. Recently, Ling et al. [54] have introduced a Lewis acidic layer (Cr2O3) onto a common catalyst (CoO x ), which leads to a local alkaline microenvironment around the anode in neutral seawater, thereby achieving extremely high OER activity and 100% selectivity. This is attributed to the dynamic capture of *OH ions by the rigid Lewis acid layer, representing a universally applicable design strategy. The insights from Lewis's acid-base theory provide crucial theoretical guidance for the realization of direct seawater electrolysis. Furthermore, it is imperative to develop and apply more theoretical methods tailored around direct seawater electrolysis to guide the synthesis of electrocatalysts with excellent activity and selectivity. Secondly, it remains challenging to predict the adsorption, migration, and desorption processes of Cl‒ and oxygen-containing intermediates, which are critical for enhancing the stability and selectivity of the anode. This challenge is compounded by the limitations of conventional characterization methods. The integration of machine learning algorithms with an automated testing platform offers an expedited approach to elucidate novel corrosion mechanisms and competitive reaction pathways during seawater electrolysis. The electrochemical tests and characterization analyses can be conducted efficiently using the automated testing platform, thereby generating a substantial, high-precision database for machine learning algorithms to monitor the density distribution of key intermediates. Furthermore, in the process of seawater electrolysis, the corrosion mechanisms induced by Cl‒ at individual metal sites require further investigation. The combination of STEM-EELS and high-speed single-photon detection is anticipated to shed light on the adsorption, migration, and dissociation processes of Cl‒ at metal sites during electrochemical reactions. STEM-EELS can provide atomic-level details of Cl‒ in various locations. High-speed single-photon detection enables real-time monitoring of the dynamic processes of Cl‒ corrosion and competitive reactions in electrochemical reactions. Consequently, the synergy of characterization techniques is instrumental in comprehending Cl‒ corrosion and competitive reactions at the electrolytic seawater anode. Thirdly, the design criteria of cathode HER should be paid attention to combine with the design methods of OER catalyst mentioned above. In alkaline environment, the catalytic performance of the anode can be maximized, but this is not conducive to directly providing H* for HER, which will limit the overall seawater splitting. In addition, in the process of natural seawater splitting, OH* produced in the cathodic water dissociation step (Vomler) can directly provide raw materials for OER. Therefore, it is necessary to develop vacancy engineering, high entropy alloy, heterostructure and doping to accelerate the kinetics of water dissociation and proton transfer. In this regard, designing a bifunctional electrocatalyst can effectively promote natural seawater splitting and reduce the investment in research and material costs. Fourth, in the integration of industrial electrolyzers with electrocatalysts, the corrosion and replacement costs of the catalysts and equipment are significant factors that cannot be overlooked. To address this, electrolyzers can benefit from a modular design approach and optimized operational conditions, such as pH and temperature control, which may effectively mitigate the costs associated with replacement and corrosion. Similarly, for eletrocatalysts, the development of regeneration technologies is a viable strategy to reduce costs through removing by-products and vacancies from the electrode surface. The integrating anode material development with electrolyzer design holds great promise for achieving large-scale and integrated production of seawater electrolysis. References 1 S. Chen T. Zhang J. Jingqi Chi received her B.S. degree and Ph.D. degree from the State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum (East China). She is currently an associate professor at Qing dao University of Science and Technology. Her research interests focus on the design and synthesis of transition metal-based nanostructures and porous MOFs materials for electrochemical applications. Lei Wang was awarded a Ph.D. in chemistry from Jilin University in 2006 under the supervision of Prof. Shouhua Feng. He worked as a Postdoctoral Scholar in Shandong University, the State Key Laboratory of Crystal Materials from 2008 to 2010. He is currently a professor at Qingdao University of Science and Technology. His research interests mainly focus on the design and synthesis of functional organic-inorganic hybrids and porous MOFs materials, as well as their applications in photocatalysis, electrocatalysis, lithium-ion battery, etc.

coredata.dc:description: At present, seawater electrolysis powered by renewable energy stands as a crucial method for the industrial production of hydrogen. Given the abundance of seawater and its inherently high conductivity, seawater electrolysis earns an increasing interest. Nonetheless, challenges remain, such as the competitive chloride oxidation reaction (COR) caused by chloride ions (Cl‒) and the corrosion of active sites, which hinder the industrial seawater electrolysis. In this review, we initially outline four design strategies aimed at avoiding the occurrence of COR: designing selective oxygen evolution reaction (OER) active sites, anti-corrosion strategies, small molecules oxidize reaction (SMOR) and adjusting electrolyte. Specifically, we compile approaches to enhance the OER selectivity and corrosion resistance in seawater electrolysis, including introducing anion buffer layer. Subsequently, we categorize reported OER catalysts based on their composition and summarize the mechanism underlying their high activity and stability. In conclusion, we address the future challenges and prospects of industrializing seawater electrolysis.
